bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, May 11, 1950

div1.p: The plaque honoring Reed will soon be installed at Fort McNair. He will send Hench a photo of the plaque after its installation. Siler has not heard from Wallach since his original visit to Washington.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, May 11, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
_____
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
May 11, 1950
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you so very much for your note of May 3rd anclosing a copy of
your letter to Mr. Wallach.

I don't know when I have regretted anything so much as my having been
unable to hear your talk here in Washington and see you in person at that time.
I am delighted you were able to see the bronze tablet.

The plaque was received by the authorities at Ft. McNair several days
ago and Major Simpson, the Engineer Officer, called me yesterday and said they
were ready to install it and would like for us to come out and give them advice
concerning the details of its installation. I was able to get in touch with
General Reed and General Albert Love and we went down this morning and met the
Post Commander and Post Engineer Officer at ten o'clock. They had made all
preliminary plans and had the plaque tentatively placed on a concrete foundation.
We all thought the height at which they had installed it to be the proper one
and they were going ahead to complete the work.

As soon as there is a chance I hope to be able to get a photograph
of it and will send you a print for your information and files.

Thanks very much for the copy of the letter you wrote Mr. Wallach.
I have heard nothing from him since his original visit to Washington some time
ago. As a matter of fact, as I have written you heretofore, under present
conditions I think it to be very foolish to spend $350,000 in the next three
years merely for publicity purposes. General Kean and General Reed and others
who are interested in Walter Reed feel as I do about the matter. I have not
heard anything further as to the status of the bill but should I hear anything
I will be glad to advise you. If there is any intention of spending any such
amount, it would be so much better to have a trust fund and use the income for
research along lines we know Walter Reed would appreciate.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler jfs k
